instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PM_SLP_S4: What is PM_SLP_S4? This is a typo of PM_SLP_S4_L When you see PM_SLP_S4, assume they meant to type PM_SLP_S4_L.
definitions.PP1V8_S3: What is PP1V8_S3? The PP1V8_S3 signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that provides a voltage of 1.8 volts during the S3 power state. The S3 state, often referred to as "suspend to RAM," is a low-power mode where the computer saves the session's state to RAM, allowing for quicker wake-up times compared to a full shutdown..
definitions.P5VS0_EN: What is P5VS0_EN? This signal enables the PP5V_S0 power rail when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.P1V8S3_PGOOD: What is P1V8S3_PGOOD? P1V8S3_PGOOD is a signal that denotes that the PP1V8_S3 power rail is working..
definitions.PP5V_S4R3: What is PP5V_S4R3? This is a typo of PP5V_S4RS3 When you see PP5V_S4R3, assume they meant to type PP5V_S4RS3.
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Strange Issue, help!
threads.message:
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>

The Logic Board does not turn on, when attached to my power supply it will take 30Mah, then quickly 19Mah, then to about 160 for a split second, then back to 30. I have narrowed down the problem to <CHIP>U8080</CHIP>, and the <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4R3</SIGNAL> rail. It seems like there is a short to ground, however I have checked every connection to this and there is no short. <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4R3</SIGNAL> will go to 0V, then to about 2V for a split second (when it goes it 160 mAH). When I remove <CHIP>U8080</CHIP>, this goes away, and the board stays at 160mah, when removed I checked every connection and no short.

<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> will sometimes be there, it has occurred twice now where when I measure <RESISTOR>R8116</RESISTOR>, and others around it, the board will be OK, and even when <CHIP>U8080</CHIP> is there the logic board goes to 160mAH.

I can compare the symptoms to Louis Rossmanns <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> video, where the S4 and S3 rails are affected by this.

I have replaced <CHIP>U8080</CHIP> twice, and have replaced <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> too.

EDIT: When removing <CHIP>U8080</CHIP>, <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4</SIGNAL> is present and working. As well as <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4R3</SIGNAL>, and <SIGNAL>P5VS0_EN</SIGNAL> (However it is at 3V, is this normal?)

EDIT: Got it working, however not fully, <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4R3</SIGNAL> is good, however <CHIP>U7820</CHIP> is not outputting <SIGNAL>P1V8S3_PGOOD</SIGNAL>. All voltages are present too, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> (3.3V), <SIGNAL>PP1V8_S3</SIGNAL> (3V), <SIGNAL>P1V8S3_FB</SIGNAL> (0.8V) , <SIGNAL>P1V8S3_SW</SIGNAL>, (1.8V)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Strange Issue, help!
threads.message:
"Got it working, however not fully"
Do you mean the board stays on, but no activity?

"<CHIP>U7820</CHIP> is not outputting <SIGNAL>P1V8S3_PGOOD</SIGNAL>"
Then you miss <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>, as VCORE too.
Remove <RESISTOR>R8166</RESISTOR> and test again.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Strange Issue, help!
threads.message:
Yep, sorry, Incorrect working. The board now pulls 150Mah, the new problem is <CHIP>U7820</CHIP> is not outputting the PGOOD signal. Yes that means no <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>.

This board does not boot or power on, before the 5V rail was down, no fan spin, now that it is fixed we do get a fan spin.

WIll remove resistor then report back.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Strange Issue, help!
threads.message: Removed resistor, still 0V, no short to ground on <CHIP>U7820</CHIP> either, all power inputs on that chip are present and correct.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Strange Issue, help!
threads.message:
If board stays on and <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> is 0V, then another power good signal pulls it down.

Check all signals involved in <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> generation.
Start removing <TRANSISTOR>Q8150</TRANSISTOR>; is a redundant protection...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Strange Issue, help!
threads.message:
Sorry for this really late reply, I have solved the problem.

For future reference or for anyone who has this problem, it was <RESISTOR>R6130</RESISTOR>, it was measuring incorrectly in resistance.

I replaced it and board fully powers on now.
